articles.headline: The iPhone Matches Most of Its Hype
articles.snippet: Apple’s new phone does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.
articles.abstract: Apple’s new phone does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk about hype. In the last six months, Apple’s iPhone has been the subject of 11,000 print articles, and it turns up about 69 million hits on Google. Cultists are camping out in front of Apple stores; bloggers call it the “Jesus phone.” All of this before a single consumer has even touched the thing.

articles.headline: Waiting for the Latest in Wizardry
articles.snippet: Apple, known for its marketing wizardry, has apparently convinced thousands of people that the iPhone is no ordinary phone.
articles.abstract: Apple, known for its marketing wizardry, has apparently convinced thousands of people that the iPhone is no ordinary phone.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 — At the Apple store on Fifth Avenue in New York, the first in line are already camped out. Sightings of the device already in the possession of a privileged few were being reported, even photographed and posted on the Internet. Rumors have it that shipments are arriving in the dark of night, accompanied by armed guards.

articles.headline: Accord Seen on Oversight of Journal
articles.snippet: The move is an important step toward a purchase by the News Corporation of The Wall Street Journal’s owner, Dow Jones.
articles.abstract: The move is an important step toward a purchase by the News Corporation of The Wall Street Journal’s owner, Dow Jones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Negotiators reached an agreement in principle yesterday on protecting the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal, an important step toward a purchase by the News Corporation of The Journal’s owner, Dow Jones & Company, people briefed on the talks said.

articles.headline: Pointing to Stability, Kurds in Iraq Lure Investors
articles.snippet: The Kurdish region of Iraq is hoping to challenge Dubai as the Middle East’s main transportation and business hub.
articles.abstract: The Kurdish region of Iraq is hoping to challenge Dubai as the Middle East’s main transportation and business hub.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — It is a measure of soaring Kurdish optimism that government officials here talk seriously about one day challenging Dubai as the Middle East’s main transportation and business hub.

articles.headline: MySpace, Chasing YouTube, Upgrades Its Offerings
articles.snippet: A new service called MySpace TV will be set up as an independent Web site that people can visit to share and watch video.
articles.abstract: A new service called MySpace TV will be set up as an independent Web site that people can visit to share and watch video.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 — Two years ago, millions of MySpace users began adding video clips to their profile pages, helping to give rise to YouTube, which Google bought last October for $1.65 billion.

articles.headline: Worthy Goal of Flawed Bill: Aiding Unions
articles.snippet: It can be tempting to think of labor unions as an antagonistic relic of an industrial economy and to forget about their lingering impact.
articles.abstract: It can be tempting to think of labor unions as an antagonistic relic of an industrial economy and to forget about their lingering impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1949, the men who ran the steelworkers’ union decided to pick a fight over health insurance and pensions.

articles.headline: 2 Oil Firms Are Defiant in Venezuela
articles.snippet: ConocoPhillips and Exxon Mobil refused to meet Venezuela’s deadline for ceding control of major oil ventures, a move that could mean the loss of billions in investments.
articles.abstract: ConocoPhillips and Exxon Mobil refused to meet Venezuela’s deadline for ceding control of major oil ventures, a move that could mean the loss of billions in investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, June 26 — ConocoPhillips and Exxon Mobil refused on Tuesday to meet Venezuela’s deadline to reach an agreement on ceding control of their major oil production ventures, in what could be their imminent separation from billions of dollars in investments.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Clifford Krauss
